Draven really doesn't need a rework. He's a niche in the ADC lane as "go hard or go home". Draven doesn't do well unless fed and when he's fed he's a bastard, which is the point of him.  He's built to do it, he does that well, and he's honestly got counterplay to him if a bit straightforward.

Draven has three little quirks that combine and make him a terrible design.

1. He scales extremely well
2. He has the highest snowballing potential in the game
3. He has best-in-class early game damage

This means that any time Draven is strong, he is almost guaranteed to win lane, then he snowballs due to his passive, which gives him items which supplement his insane scaling.

He used to not scale extremely well not because of his stats but because when it came to teamfights he had the issue that catching his axes was a chore above all else, often resulting in him being CC'd out of a ton of his damage or dropping an axe due to it falling in a shitty spot.

Then cue Death's Dance where he's not so easily bursted. 33% of initial damage becomes bleed on a massive damage output. This gave him a pretty good round of defensive measures in addition to his offensive ones that he used to not see. That was when the item was added in S6. He wasn't grossly OP but he became a little less bearable.

Then cue the support item changes. Now he also has even more damage mitigation and attention on him so that he can survive to do his asinine damage and can stand to go balls deep or just drop the occasional axe.

The issue isn't Draven or his kit. It's that itemization and balance right now is fucked out the ass on an unreal level.

Skirting the line between "ADC in 2017" and "ADC in 2017" is a tough one. Ultimately, understanding and building towards the union of what would make designers at Riot happy with the game and also what players find fun, engaging and variant game to game is quite a challenge. 

Marksmen have a unique power curve, such that just nerfing them doesn't make much of an impact by itself. By supporting a late game fantasy, it almost by definition makes them quite hard to deal with late game. The balancing factor is that both teams have one, so they kind of neutralise each other. Ideally, most designers would prefer that teams can play variant classes of characters in the "support lane", but the way the game is constructed right now, Marksmen are pretty much the way to go due to their tower killing proficiency and late game scaling. 

Ideally, the best solution in this space is to find something that both players and designers are aligned on (eg. players feel like all roles have agency, designers feel like you can do any number of meaningfully different strategies to win). 

TLDR is that nerfing marksman doesn't automatically solve the problem. If players are inherently not happy about skirting the boundary between either ADC's being unable to touch tanks or ADC's being too powerful, it's possible that exploring some more fundamental changes to the way ADC's function is a potential option - which of course carry different costs and benefits.

There's a clear rock-paper-scissors relationship in league between burst-sustained-tank. But the mage update, the assassin update, and the tank update largely messed with the power of burst champions (the tank update nerfed itemization for divers. And now divers don't get their own class update, they don't have their own itemization coming). So now burst is bad, and we have a cycle of DPS and tanks.

I agree. 
In my experience, ADC have always been the least liked role after support, because of how intrinsecally difficult to play they are: while a mage can drop her combo and call it a day (and die knowing they did their job), an ADC has to stay alive AND output damage, if he dies at the start of the teamfight his contribution is zero. Another problem is that while mages are definde by their spells, ADCs' main damage output comes from autoattacks, and those work basically the same for most of them, making it difficult to make them really different. I think there are a few ADCs who feel different to play (Graves, Ezreal, Quinn, Twitch, Lucian), but most hypercarries just rely on autoattacking a lot (tristana, kog, jinx, sivir,...)

This season ardent censer was quite clearly the meta-warper, and it helped ADCs a lot. But that's far from being a problem of the AD Carry role/class, imo :)

I actually think they've mostly done a good job now of making different adcs feel different to play

And imo their lack of popularity just comes from being part of a duo lane. I thoroughly enjoy playing adc and support both but i don't think I'd ever main either role because you're so reliant on teammates and each other

People agree on changing the fundamentals of adc but usually what's discussed is deleting crit or giving "OP" carries ammo systems and things like that

I honestly think you need to go back to the items,  no one cared about hypercarries until EVERY CRIT ITEM GOT BUFFED!  Like individually these things are minor but the decision was made to buff the IE + Zeal item spike by making it cheaper when it already was the best dps combo late game, and BoRKs changes made it better for AS based carries who need to survive early game.  Items will affect both the strongest and weakest carries, and there hasn't been a change to anything affecting adc this season other than censer which while getting nerfed is still the strongest support item for the fact its such an efficient on-hit.

I think if Ardent didn't exist hypercarries wouldn't be such a problem since their powerspike would be more delayed, but I think we'd still see lategame focus with how good crit in general is.  However as is the fact supports rush ardent means that when an ADC is at one big item they're actually at 2 big items in-game, which has never been an issue with the class before and totally disrupts the powerspike.  IMO you should just cut AS from Ardent or something that stops it from being a powerspike, I honestly feel the on-hit healing or something defensive would be preferrable as an effect since most support items are cc or defense, its never been an issue until you gave contribution to the powerspike of your carry.  

I know build diversity is important but Ardent has only DECREASED diversity or been a non-option since its inception, which has been a pattern for items that get deleted from the game.  If you want this item to contribute to an ADC's powerspike I think removing its AS component and making it more on-hit based would at least force you to buy a complete AS item to get value out of it without it instantly turning Twitch and Kog into team shredders.  That or you can nerf every AS item that exists or nerf crit as a stat to make the values of Ardent feel fair.  I personally think the existance of crit hurts a lot of playmaking potential ADCs might otherwise be allowed to have early game, so nerfing how much it hurts or how much crit chance is on items may be a suitable option but until Censer is properly dealt with I don't think we're in a good spot to assess ADC balance.
But hyper carries weren't used until every crit item got buffed...save Caitlyn ruining everyone's fun.
